subject: RE: [junit] Best practice - should I fake, or depend on real worl	d objects?
msgSnippet: ... setting ... the ... using ... serialization/deserialization. Perhaps my post was confusing.  I *have* a seperate set of serialisation/deserialisation tests
messageBody:
Jonathan Oddy wrote:

> > JB responded:
> >
> > > Jonathan Oddy wrote:
> > >
> > >> Does this seem like a resonable direction to be going - or am I
setting
> > >> myself up for an unpleasant (unforseen) fall somewhere later down
the
> > track?
> > >>
> > >> Any thoughts/criticisms welcome.
> > >
> > > Quick question: what are you trying to test? Deserialization? or
using
> > > the deserialized object? Both?
> >
> > The later (is that the right answer?)

> If you're testing both, then test them separately. It looks like your
> deserialization headaches are affecting your ability to test using the
> deserialized object. Stop. Write some tests for
serialization/deserialization.

Perhaps my post was confusing. I *have* a seperate set of
serialisation/deserialisation tests that have nothing to do with the tests I
mentioned in my original post.

> Write some tests for using the object.
> For the "using the object" tests, just create the objects in memory and
> use them, rather than deseralizing them.

I think this is what I am/was doing. However (almost) all of these "data
type" objects are only "constructed" through the deserialisation process -
they don't have constructors with 20+ arguments (may be they should, or may
be these data objects should be refactored into smaller classes...). So
when I come to use them during testing (because the method under test uses
them) I have a decision to make - should I (1) fake; (2) use the
deserialisation process to construct a "real" object; or (3) add a
constructor that takes 20+ parameters and construct my in memory object that
way. So far, depending on the nature of the test I've been doing (1) and
(2). It's just that recently (probably because I am lazy I don't know) I've
noticed that I've been using (2) a whole lot more.

> > I have a number of deserialisation tests for those classes being
> > deserialised - so that's not what I am testing here. I am simply using
the
> > fact that I "know" I have a "working" deserialisation process on some
class
> > "A" to speed up my test creation process. It is much easier to
data-scrape
> > an objects serialised form from a log file and use an object
constructed
> > from that within my test than to fake it.

> Why not just create the object in memory? Why deserialize one?

Because, currently (as intimated in my previous comment) I don't have the
ability to create the object in memory as the object(s) in question only
have default constructors and no setters (they're immutable). Currently the
only way to get a *useful* in memory object is to either (1) fake it, or (2)
use the object's built in deserialisation code. The main advantage of (2)
is it gives me a bonefide object to use with no externally built assumptions
(other than the data from which it was "constructed" (deserialised) - but
then I'd have that same problem with my 20+ argument constructor).

So my original question rephrased was: I want to depend on as little as
possible and when I do I'd prefer, where practical, to depend on "real"
objects rather than fakes, however as most of my data objects follow the
"deserialised construction idiom" (I might just have made that term up) I
was querying whether there might be a better way of achieving this.
